importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident when Houthi rebels detained 20 UN employees and raided a UN facility in Sanaa, marking a significant escalation in the conflict over humanitarian operations in Yemen.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The ongoing conflict and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, with the Houthi crackdown on UN personnel intensifying in 2025, reflects a persistent threat to international humanitarian efforts and global stability.

keyTakeAways: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels detained 20 United Nations employees in Sanaa, Yemen, including five Yemenis and 15 international staff.
The rebels confiscated all communication equipment, including phones, servers, and computers, from the facility.
The detained staff belong to multiple UN agencies, including the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
This is part of a broader crackdown by the Houthis against UN and international organizations in rebel-held areas such as Sanaa, Hodeida, and Saada.
The UN has previously suspended operations in Saada province and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden due to similar detentions.
The Houthis have accused detained staff of being spies, but the UN has consistently denied these allegations.
A World Food Program worker died in detention earlier in 2025 in Saada, highlighting the dangers faced by humanitarian personnel.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen detained 20 United Nations employees, including 15 international staff and five Yemenis, in a raid on a facility in Sanaa. The rebels confiscated all communication equipment, disrupting humanitarian operations. The detainees come from multiple UN agencies, including WFP, UNICEF, and OCHA. This follows a broader pattern of Houthi crackdowns targeting international organizations, with previous detentions leading to operational suspensions in Saada and relocation of UN leadership to Aden. The Houthis have accused staff of espionage, which the UN denies. A WFP worker died in detention earlier in 2025, underscoring the risks faced by humanitarian personnel in conflict zones.
title: Yemen’s Houthi rebels detain 20 UN employees and confiscate equipment
